metadata.title: Bio-Nano-Interaction in Treatment and Management of Cancer

sections.text:
JES FOCUS ISSUE ON 4D MATERIALS AND SYSTEMS
Bio-Nano-Interaction in Treatment and Management of Cancer Ahmad Sohrabi Kashani,1 Simona Badilescu,1 Alisa Piekny,2 and Muthukumaran Packirisamy 1,z
1Optical Bio-Microsystem Lab., Mechanical, Industrial, and Aerospace Engineering Department of Concordia University, Montreal, Quebec H3G 1M8 Canada 2Biology Department, Concordia University, Montreal, Quebec H3G 1M8 Canada
Due to the excellent biocompatibility of gold nanoparticles with human organism, they have great potentials for controlled drug delivery, cancer detection, cancer therapy, cancer management, and biomedical imaging. The unique optical and physiochemical properties of gold nanoparticles have made them a great candidate for intracellular diagnosis using surface-enhanced Raman microscopy and hyperspectral microscopy. These two techniques offer sensitive and non-invasive measurements. Gold nanoparticles also can be utilized to modulate the mechanobiological properties of cells, providing a platform to suppress the metastatic level of cells. © The Author(s) 2018. Published by ECS. This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives 4.0 License (CC BY-NC-ND, http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/), which permits non-commercial reuse, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is not changed in any way and is properly cited. For permission for commercial reuse, please email: oa@electrochem.org. [DOI: 10.1149/2.0021909jes]
Manuscript submitted October 23, 2018; revised manuscript received November 30, 2018. Published December 20, 2018. This paper is part of the JES Focus Issue on 4D Materials and Systems.
Cancer is one of the most common causes of death in the world, and according to the World Health Organization’s World Cancer Report 2014, the number of deaths from cancer is estimated to climb to 22 million by 2035.1 Over the past decades, many efforts have been done to develop new and better approaches for the detection and treatment of cancer. Surgical excision, irradiation, and chemotherapy are the three main conventional therapies. All these methods cause damage to the healthy tissues, or the eradication of cancer cannot be performed completely.2 The solubility of drugs, the lack of a precise targeting, non-specific distribution, and multidrug resistance after cancer chemotherapy, are some of the other limitations of the conventional approaches which have made their application in cancer treatment not satisfactory. Developing techniques allowing agents to be delivered only to the tumors’ sites, without causing negative effects on the healthy tissues and organs is one of the urgent needs in the cancer treatment. In recent years, the application of nanotechnology in medicine and drug delivery has been increasing rapidly. Nanotechnology provides a tremendous opportunity for designing nanomaterials with favorable properties, nanomedicine, for site-specific drug delivery.3 Among different nanoparticles which are developed for nanomedicine applications, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have shown remarkable optical and physicochemical properties which have made them a good candidate for the detection and treatment of cancer. Gold nanoparticles are relatively biologically inert, so they can be used for in vivo applications. Due to localized surface plasma resonance (LSPR), they have invaluable optical properties enabling them to be used as a sensor. AuNPs can be functionalized with different kinds of biomolecules such as drugs, genes and targeting ligands. Biocompatibility and internalization ability are two determining factors for choosing AuNPs for biomedical applications (Figure 1).
In this perspective, we briefly review recent advances in studying the interaction of AuNPs and cancer cells, and methods for intracellular diagnosis are described. Then, the potential of gold nanoparticles to modulate the biophysical properties of cancer cells is discussed.

sections.heading: Current Status on AuNPs-Cancer Cells Interactions
sections.text:
Before using AuNPs for the detection and treatment of cancers, it is necessary to investigate how these particles interact with cells or biological entities inside and outside cells. It has been shown that,
zE-mail: mpackir@encs.concordia.ca
depending on their physiochemical parameters such as size, surface chemistry, shape, and coating material, AuNPs can be either toxic or non-toxic to the cells. However, the effects of other factors and conditions such as cells size,4 cell type,5 cell sex,6 exposure time, concentration,7 and protein adoration8 have not to be overlooked when assessing cytotoxicity. Understanding the effects of different parameters of nanoparticles enables to redesign them to enhance their accumulation in the tumor.9 The impacts of physicochemical properties of AuNPs on their toxicity and internalization are briefly discussed as follows:
Size of nanoparticles.—Cellular uptake of AuNPs is strongly dependent on the size of particles. Endocytosis is the main biological mechanism, allowing AuNPs to enter cells. During this process, nanoparticles are engaged with some proteins on the membrane of cells such as clathrin and caveolin and then are engulfed by cells.10,11 The cellular uptake efficiency of nanoparticles, internalization mechanics and subcellular distribution are influenced by the AuNPs size. In one of our previous studies, we observed that smaller particles localized more uniformly in HeLa cells (cytosol) while larger particles are distributed more randomly.9 Many studies have shown that AuNPs with sizes in the range of 30–50 (nm) exhibit the maximum cellular uptake, suggesting that there is an optimal size for efficient uptake.12 The size of nanoparticles likely affects the wrapping process by the membrane for receptor-mediated endocytosis. Thermodynamically, particles with a size of 50 nm bind effectively with enough receptors on the membrane, enabling them to successfully enter the cells. Moreover, the size of nanoparticles may affect their toxicity toward cells, and smaller particles appear to be more toxic, compared to larger particles. Smaller particles possess high surface area relative to their volume, so they are able to interact more effectively with the cellular and subcellular components. Due to their smaller size, they have a better chance to penetrate intracellular locations and even nucleus and to interact with the genetic material.13
Shape of nanoparticles.—Gold nanoparticles can be fabricated with different shapes such as spheres,14 rods, stars,15 triangles,16 plates,17 and primes.18 Nanoparticles, depending on their shape, might interact differently with different cellular and subcellular components. The geometry of AuNPs influences their ability to enter cells and alter their localization in cells. Particles due to their different contact area with the membrane of cells exhibit different ability to enter cells. Nanospheres and nanorods with low aspect ratio show the highest
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 5.101.221.99Downloaded on 2019-01-20 to IP
internalization ability. By increasing the rods’ aspect ratio, their cellular uptake is significantly decreased, and they need a longer time for membrane wrapping.19
Functionalization of nanoparticles.—Functionalizing AuNPs with biomolecules, peptide ligands, antibodies or different chemical groups, will influence their internalization ability. Cell surface receptors may recognize these molecules and allow them to penetrate cells. As the interaction of nanoparticles and cells occurs at the interface of cells and particles, surface properties of AuNPs play a dominant role in cell uptake. Coating the surface of AuNPs can change their stability and biocompatibility. Polyethylene glycol (PEG) is one of the commonly used ligands for AuNPs. Grabinski et al. studied the effects of two different ligands: mercaptohexadecanoic acid (MHDA) and thiolated polyethylene glycol (PEG) on the cellular uptake of gold nanorods in HaCaT cells. Their findings indicate that cellular uptake of PEG-nanorods is relatively low compared to MHDA-nanorods.20
Apart from the surface ligands, the surface charge may alter the internalization level of AuNPs. Several investigations have shown that AuNPs with positive charge have higher internalization level in cells. The cell membrane displays a strong negative charge due to phosphate groups of lipids, so positively charged AuNPs are absorbed much more on the cell membrane, compared to the natural and negatively charged nanoparticles.21
Future needs and prospects.—Despite the rapid development in designing nanoparticles for cancer therapy, their clinical practices for cancer treatment has not been very impressive. In order to achieve effective therapeutic responses, the drug should be delivered to precise locations at the cellular and intracellular levels. Therefore, understanding the intracellular location of AuNPs is a critical step in designing nanoparticles-based drug delivery systems. For many diseases, alternation can happen at the nanoscale, inside the cells such as subcellular organelles (mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, etc.). The precise detection of nanoparticles at subcellular level enables us to improve drug delivery systems and prevent drugs from a random distribution. Nanoparticles uptake evaluation and their intracellular distribution play a significant role in the design and development of successful drug delivery systems. Therefore, developing advanced methods for intracellular detection is very essential. Determining the intracellular status of AuNPs in cells such as their intracellular aggregation, intracellular localizations, their direct and indirect interactions with
subcellular components, and targeting specific organelles are other challenges in intracellular-targeted therapy. Moreover, cell mechanic plays a significant role in the function of cells and can provide an indication for the healthy level of cells. However, few studies have been focused on cell-nanoparticles interaction in the context of cell mechanics. Study the impacts of nanoparticles on mechanobiological properties of cells can enhance our understanding of nano-bio-interactions. In the following, the perspective of intracellular diagnoses, as well as cell mechanics for nano-bio-interaction, are discussed.
Developing tools for intracellular diagnosis of AuNPs.—Gold nanoparticles offer unique optical properties such as scattering, absorption, and localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR).22,23 LSPR properties of AuNPs provide great opportunities to develop nanoparticle-based sensors for rapid and ultra-sensitive detection of biological entities. In order to design nanomedicines for cancer therapy, this property of AuNPs can be utilized to detect and track nanoparticles at a subcellular level. There are several methods, allowing the detection and tracking of AuNPs in cells such as fluorescence microscopy, photo thermal microscopy,24 transmission electron microscopy (TEM),25 differential interference contract (DIC),26 electron microscopy and dark-field microscopy.27 However, these experimental methods are time-consuming in sample preparation and have their own limitations. Some of such techniques have been reviewed elsewhere,28,29 and here, we will focus specifically on hyperspectral microscopy (HPM) and surface enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) for intracellular diagnosis. SERS and HPM methods not only offer simple, non-invasive, label-free and powerful techniques for detection of AuNPs in cells but also, in contrast to other methods, provide information on how AuNPs interact with intracellular compartments.
Hyperspectral microscopy for intracellular measurement.—Hyperspectral microscopy is a novel technique in which spectrophotometry and imaging are coupled, based on the dark-field reflectance systems, allowing us to determine nanoparticles in a biological environment.30,31 Dark-field microscopy is able to provide the incoming reflected light from the sample and not from the background, allowing to eliminate the background noises. Therefore, this system enables us to observe low-contrast objects such as nanoparticles with a high resolution. This non-invasive method provides a system of measurement to obtain spectral and spatial information simultaneously in one measurement. The combination of optical observation and
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 5.101.221.99Downloaded on 2019-01-20 to IP
spectral-spatial characterization of nanomaterials in a biological environment not only enables us to identify the presence of nanoparticles but also to locate them in cells. This measurement system provides a non-contact and powerful approach for the identification and characterization of nanoparticles in cells necessary for designing drug delivery systems. Depending on the size, shape, surface chemistry and interaction of AuNPs with the surrounding environment, the LSPR band of AuNPs may be located from visible to near-infrared wavelength. The capability of hyperspectral imaging for visual identification and quantitative characterization of nanomaterials allows to confirm the internalization of AuNPs as well as reveal their optical properties for possible intracellular plasmonic detection.
Enhanced dark-field hyperspectral images can be used for localization of AuNPs in cells and their characterization in different regions of cells. In our recent work, we used this technique to observe trapped AuNPs and Swarna Bhasma (Incinerated Indian gold particles) in HeLa cells. It was observed that AuNPs, depending on their location inside the cells, exhibit different spectral profiles, showing that AuNPs interact differently with different intracellular components.32,33 It was found that the width and position of peaks are completely different for AuNPs at the periphery and inside of the cells (Figure 2). The comparison of two different concentrations of AuNPs in HeLa cells (high and low) showed that the effects of the surrounding environment are more predominant when the number of internalized particles is lower. The different responses of particles in cells confirm the intracellular plasmonic sensing concept with which the distribution of particles in cells can be determined for drug delivery applications.
Surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) for intracellular measurement.—Surface Enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) has attracted great attention to study cell-nanoparticle interaction and investigate nanoparticles localization in cells. This system provides a high-sensitive and non-destructive measurement for tracking nanoparticles in cells. Raman spectroscopy can provide very weak vibrational responses of active molecules in cells.34 When noble metals such as AuNPs are situated in the vicinity of these molecules the inelastic light scattering is enhanced by several orders. This enhancement occurs due to the excitation of LSPR of metal nanoparticles by incident light; however, the role of the chemical enhancement caused by the interaction of particles and molecules cannot be ignored in the enhancement.35 SERS provides high sensitive, label-free and non-destructive measurement, offering a useful technique for localization of nanoparticles
in cells, essential for designing targeted therapy. Moreover, with this technique, a complete structural characterization of target molecules can be performed by internalization of AuNPs, allowing to understand how AuNPs interact with the surrounding environment. In contrast to other methods which can only provide the visual identification of nanoparticles, with SERS, the effects of nanoparticles on the biochemical changes can be investigated. Shah et al. used the SERS method to monitor the dynamic uptake of AuNPs and their localization in prostate cells.36
AuNPs suppress metastatic level of cancer.—Gold nanoparticles can be used for controlling the biophysical properties of cells. The cytoskeletal structure of cells plays a significant role in biological functions of cells such as cell division, preserving the morphology, movement of cells and endocytosis. The cytoskeleton is composed of different proteins such as micro tubulin, actin, and intermediate filaments, giving the cell a dynamic structure. Cells are able to change their mechanobiological properties by polymerizing or depolymerizing those proteins.37,38 Measuring changes in mechanobiological properties can help us understand the biological state of cells. During cancer progression, the deformability and adhesion of cells are altered, enabling them to invade other tissue and organs. Nanomaterials such as AuNPs after internalization can somehow escape from lysosomal and endosomal vesicles and freely swim inside the cytoplasm and interact with cytoskeletal proteins. Some studies have shown that nanoparticles-protein interaction may induce changes in the mechanobiological properties of cells, causing negative effects on their biological function. The impact of nanoparticles on the mechanobiological properties depends on the physiochemical characteristic of particles such as size and shape. For instance, it has been observed that nanorods with high aspect ratio are able to largely change the organization of actin filaments, causing a serious damage to the cytoskeletal structure. The work done by Choudhury39 showed that AuNPs depending on their size and concentration may inhibit polarization of micro tubulin. They observed that due to the interaction of AuNPs with cells, micro tubulins are damaged and shrunken compared to the control cells.
The resistance of cells to the external force can also give more information regarding the healthy state of cells.40 It has been substantiated that the deformability of cancer cells is increased compared to benign cells. Cytoskeletal changes, induced by internalization of AuNPs, may affect the mechanobiological properties of cells. In some anti-cancer
) unless CC License in place (see abstract). ecsdl.org/site/terms_use address. Redistribution subject to ECS terms of use (see 5.101.221.99Downloaded on 2019-01-20 to IP
drugs such as Doxorubicin and Taxol, the cytoskeletal structure of cells is targeted to disturb the organization of cells. Therefore the organization of cells is changed and the metastatic ability of malignant cells is reduced.41 The biomechanical assessment of cells can provide more information regarding the effectiveness of anti-cancer drugs and, particularly, nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems. Atomic force microscopy (AFM), optical tweezer, micropipette, magnetic twister, MEMS and microfluidic-based devices42–44 are important tools for quantifying the mechanobiological properties. El-Sayed et al.45 claimed that gold nanorods targeted to the nucleus of ovarian cancer cells can hinder their invasion ability. They observed that the migration ability of ovarian cancer cells is decreased upon interaction with gold nanorods compared to the control cells. With AFM measurement, they showed that the stiffness of cancer cells is increased compared to non-treated cells, suppressing the metastatic ability of cells.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: AuNPs provide a versatile platform for cancer therapy and cancer management. The potential of AuNPs for cancer treatment and drug delivery have been confirmed in many in vitro evaluations. The physicochemical properties of AuNPs can be precisely designed to allow these nano-carriers to efficiently penetrate to tissue and controllably release the drugs. Intracellular diagnosis of AuNPs plays a significant role in designing nanoparticle-based drug delivery systems and estimate their effectiveness. SERS and HPM are promising methods for cancer treatment. Using HPM, nanoparticles can be designed for targeting subcellular organelles. Moreover, AuNPs can modulate the mechanobiological properties of cells. This potential of AuNPs not only can be utilized to control the invasion ability of malignant cancers but also can provide a platform for evaluating the effectiveness of drug delivery system. Despite of many promising advancements in targeted therapy, our understanding is still limited, and translation of these systems to clinical applications is challenging.

sections.text: NSERC (Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada) and CURC (Concordia Research Chair) grants of M.P. are acknowledged. The authors are also grateful to Stewart Mills from CytoViva for helpful discussion.

metadata.abstractText: Due to the excellent biocompatibility of gold nanoparticles with human organism, they have great potentials for controlled drug delivery, cancer detection, cancer therapy, cancer management, and biomedical imaging. The unique optical and physiochemical properties of gold nanoparticles have made them a great candidate for intracellular diagnosis using surface-enhanced Raman microscopy and hyperspectral microscopy. These two techniques offer sensitive and non-invasive measurements. Gold nanoparticles also can be utilized to modulate the mechanobiological properties of cells, providing a platform to suppress the metastatic level of cells. © The Author(s) 2018. Published by ECS. For permission for commercial reuse, please email: oa@electrochem.org. [DOI: 10.1149/2.0021909jes]
